title: Family of man stabbed to death for his bike say ‘we feel robbed of his life’
text:
Leo Marcus was killed in the street weeks before his 23rd birthday (Picture: supplied)

A family who lost a son, uncle and brother to London’s knife crime epidemic say no-one should ever have to feel their pain.

Leo Marcus, 22, was stabbed to death in an alleyway earlier this year. It is understood he was killed for refusing to give up his bike to thieves.

In the weeks after his death, his family were horrified to learn there is no minimum sentence for carrying a knife.

They believe that if there was a stronger deterrent against having a knife in place, Leo may still be alive today.

Anthony and Natalie Marcus, Leo’s brother and sister-in-law, first heard he had been stabbed in a phone call from his father Cliff.

They rushed to the hospital where they spent the next five and a half hours waiting for news of Leo’s condition before being told he would not survive his injuries.

Natalie told Metro.co.uk: ‘We were all there praying that it was going to be ok and we honestly thought it would.

‘We never ever thought that he was not going to make it.’

Leo’s family are desperate that his death makes a difference to other young people (Picture: supplied)

Leo (third from right) at the wedding of his brother Anthony and sister-in-law Natalie (Picture: supplied)

She added: ‘When the doctor came down to tell us that he wasn’t going to make it, my husband turned to me and broke down and said, “how can I tell my younger brothers that he’s dead”.

‘We just can’t believe he’s gone. We feel totally, totally robbed of his life.’

Leo had a smile that could light up a room, Natalie said. He was killed on 10 July in Woolwich, south-east London, exactly three weeks before his 23rd birthday.

He was not part of a gang, had no criminal record, and was just riding his bike in the middle of the day as he always did, Natalie said.

The family believe his death could have easily been avoided.

She said: ‘It’s just been such a difficult process.

‘Leo was just a normal boy. He loved riding his bike. He loved his nieces and nephews.

‘It’s that realisation that someone took his life away at such a young age and so immediately. For us, this loss is going to be such a huge whole in our hearts.’

Natalie said her brother-in-law ‘lit up the room with his smile’ (Picture: supplied)

Leo was loved by his nieces and nephews (Picture: supplied)

Leo’s dad Cliff and step-mum Sarah Kerr set up a petition in the weeks following his death, calling for harsher sentences for people caught carrying knives.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Natalie said they hope Leo’s death can spark a change so that no family has to go through the pain they still feel every day.

She added: ‘We know that young people may carry knives for protection, to defend themselves. Others will because they want to go out and attack.

‘But if there was that fear that they could get in serious trouble for being found with a knife – maybe they would be less likely to pick one up.

‘Leo’s younger brothers now, they are scared. This happened just down the road from his home. They are in these streets all the time.

‘It is scary that this can happen. And it can happen to anyone. It’s a cliche but we truly never thought anything like this would happen to our family.’

Leo was killed just streets away from his family home (Picture: supplied)

‘We feel we have been totally robbed of his life’ Natalie said (Picture: supplied)

The family’s petition calling for ‘Leo’s Law’ to create a minimum sentence for knife possession hit 10,000 signatures on the day of Leo’s funeral.

Natalie said: ‘We were all in church and Leo’s dad got the alert and Cliff just stood up and said, “We’ve done it. We’ve just hit 10,000”.

‘The whole church started cheering and chanting Leo’s name. He was so, so loved.’

She and the rest of Leo’s family hope they can reach 100,000 signatures on their petition so it can be considered for debate by MPs.

Advertisement

Natalie added: ‘Leo was just the kindest person. We feel that we cannot let his death pass us by and do nothing to change the current situation on our streets.’

description: Leo Marcus was murdered in an alleyway in Woolwich, London, weeks before his 22nd birthday because he refused to give up his belongings.
